hints_html: How can we relate eigenvalues to the determinant and trace of the matrix?
hints_latex:
How can we relate eigenvalues to the determinant and trace of the
matrix?
hints_raw: How can we relate eigenvalues to the determinant and trace of the matrix?
question: B 05 (b)
sols_html:
Recall that our matrix is

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & 0 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

with one eigenvalue being, \(\lambda_1=1\). Also recall that the product of the eigenvalues is equal to the determinant of the matrix and the sum is equal to the trace. We have that tr(A)=3 and det(A)=2. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \textrm{det}(A)&=\lambda_1\lambda_2\lambda_3=\lambda_2\lambda_3=2,\\ \textrm{tr}(A)&=\lambda_1+\lambda_2+\lambda_3=1+\lambda_2+\lambda_3=3.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_2\lambda_3&=2,\\ \lambda_2+\lambda_3&=2.\end{aligned}\]

We can rearrange for \(\lambda_3\) to get \(\lambda_3^2-2\lambda_3+2=0\) which has solution

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lambda_3=1\pm{}i\end{aligned}\]

where \(i=\sqrt{-1}\). If we were to plug this in to get \(\lambda_2\) we’d get

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_2=1\mp{}i.\end{aligned}\]

This is completely unsurprising since we know that complex eigenvalues occur in complex conjugate pairs. Therefore we take one of them for \(\lambda_2\) and one for \(\lambda_3\) to get that the three eigenvalues are

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_1&=1,\\ \lambda_2&=1+i,\\ \lambda_3&=1-i.\end{aligned}\]

If you are unfamiliar of the relationship to determinant and trace to eigenvalues then we can compute the remaining terms through the characteristic polynomial. For

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & 0 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

we wish to solve (A-\(\lambda\)I)x=0. For this to have a non-trivial solution we require det(A-\(\lambda\)I)=0. Therefore we require

\[\begin{aligned} |A-\lambda{}I|= \begin{vmatrix} 3-\lambda & 1 & -3\\ -1 & 0-\lambda & 2\\ 1 & 0 & 0-\lambda \end{vmatrix} =\lambda^3-3\lambda^2+4\lambda-2=0.\end{aligned}\]

We already know that \(\lambda_1=1\) is a solution, so we can long divide the polynomial by \((\lambda-1)\) to get an equation for the remaining eigenvalues. If we do this long division we get,

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{matrix} \quad\lambda^2-2\lambda+2\\ \lambda-1\overline{)\lambda^3-3\lambda^2+4\lambda-2} \end{matrix}\end{aligned}\]

and so the other eigenvalues, \(\lambda_2\) and \(\lambda_2\) must solve the equation, \(\lambda^2-2\lambda+2\) which is the same equation we found in Solution 1. Therefore we know that the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lambda=1\pm{}i\end{aligned}\]

giving the three eigenvalues as

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_1&=1,\\ \lambda_2&=1+i,\\ \lambda_3&=1-i.\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Consider the matrix below:

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & 0 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

It is known that \(\lambda_1=1\) is an eigenvalue of A.

Find the other two eigenvalues, \(\lambda_2\) and \(\lambda_3\) of A.
